My husband loved his Mongolian Beef as well. I just wished we'd found the place early in our stay. It's only about 3 miles from the hotel and worth the bus or taxi trip (we had a rent car). Go around 2:30pm. Otherwise you'll have to wait an hour to get seated....it's that good. As for the Ilima Hotel....don't be afraid. If you're not on a limited budget and the sky's the limit....stay at the Royal Hawaiian or the Moana Hotel...the two oldest, most glorious hotels in Waikiki. But, if you're on a budget...stay at the Ilima like we did, then go to those two hotels and enjoy them for dinner. On our final night, we dropped $200 at the Royal Hawaiian for dinner and it was worth every penny as we dined on the lanai by the beach. Saving money at the Ilima allowed us this final night splurge. It also allowed us to play golf at Turtle Bay and Ko'Oalau. I guess it depends on where you place your priorities. FYI - we also had a smoking room...Ilima is one of the few hotels in Honolulu which still has a smoking floor.

This Hotel may be a bit dated but it is clean and great value. Maid service very good.Had a room on 16th floor great views. Plus point FREE parking no rip off like other hotels who charge a large amount to park your car.

As soon as we entered the lobby we were greeted warmly by the staff. We had reserved a studio for four nights and were happy to see we were on the eighth floor overlooking the canal and the mountains. What a fantastic view! The room, being over 500 sq.ft, seemed enormous compared to standard hotels, and we had plenty of space to spread out. Perhaps because we overlooked the canal, we heard very little noise late at night, although at times the wind howled, but it wasn't enough to disturb us. Nonetheless, the room, somewhat dated (who cares?) was spotless and had everything we needed, i.e. appliances, utensils, internet connection (no wi-fi yet) and so on. I had read earlier reviews so I brought coffee filters so I didn't have to buy a new batch. Having rented a car, the staff told us where to find the Safeway supermarket, around a 15 minute drive, and we loaded up on breakfast and snack items. It's a five minute walk to the International Market which has a lot of great choices for a variety of inexpensive food. Also, there's a great noodle place (I believe east on Kuhio Ave) just a few blocks away...you'll know it when you see the long lines. It's well worth the wait. Although the parking at the hotel seemed to be limited, we never had a problem getting a space. It takes less than 15 minutes to walk to the beach and there are numerous restaurants all quite near, again a very diverse selection, from Thai to Chili's, depending on your whim. So, if you're looking for a spectacular deal in a great location, this is the place to stay. Reserve online directly with the hotel to get a a special rate - look specials.

Staying here was like staying at a relative's apartment when they are away. It was clean, but a little worse for wear. It needed a paint job and new furniture in the rooms. The rooms were noisy from the wind whistling through the window slats, and a little drafty around the air conditioners. The staff seemed nice and the price was cheap for the location in Waikiki. They had a computer that guests could use near the lobby, but they charged by the minute and for printing pages, which seemed a little cheap. The parking was limited and there was no wifi (there were connections for computers) in the rooms. It did have a small outdoor pool. So, if you are looking for a cheap place in Waikiki that is clean but far from fancy, and three or four blocks to the beach, this is your place.

When you first walk in, you will feel Aloha with the very friendly & helpful staff. We were here for 4 nights w/a room on 16th flr (#1607) - we thought we would be on 9th but higher is better b/c there is still some street noise (welcome to Waikiki!). Beautiful view from lanai of mtns & lites of city & canal. The full kitchen came in handy as we bought food at Food Pantry (2-3 blks) for breakfasts & lunches even dinner one night. Yes, the hotel is 'dated' but who cares if it is a clean & very spacious room.We rented a car for 2 days to see the north end beaches & then also to go to Hanauma Bay where the snorkeling was fun (don't expect spectacular). It was cheaper to rent a car in Waikiki than at HNL airport even with a shuttle cost of $10pp to hotel & later back to airport. (Ilima will give you the ph number - reserve 24 hrs). Parking for free at hotel was a plus! Stay away from the H-1 freeway as much as possible - ridiculous traffic. (no aloha there)We will probably not revisit Waikiki again because we have enjoyed Kauai, Maui & Big Island more & will likely return to them. But the Ilima IS the place to stay if you visit Waikiki.

This property is dated. BUT the staff is very friendly.My room was noisy both due to street noise and wind whistling thru the unit. I put towels under the door to stop the whistling.The room is large, but everything is dated.

The Ilima Hotel exceeded our expectations. We were welcomed with friendly smiles and aloha as soon as we checked in for our 3 week stay. We even had a gift basket in our room upon arrival. It was clean, spacious and had a full kitchen and lanai which over looked the canal & golf course . For the value and for an older hotel the value was great. Only downfall is the pool it is like a wading pool for children but you have the ocean only 5 minutes away. Great location This was my 8th trip to Waikiki and most definitely we will stay at the Ilima again.

This is not the Hilton! However, if you want a clean, spacious, quiet room in a central location it is excellent value. We had a room with a kitchenette and the room is very spacious. Decor and furnishings are a bit outdated, but everything is very clean. Staff are very friendly and helpful. We didn't need it but parking is free. Best of all, super close to the international food court and the blue water shrimp and crab stall, which was amazing(as testified by the queues every night). Close to buses and staff know all the routes. Would definitely stay here again.

Staff was very friendly, very quiet hotel, walking distance to everything in Waikiki, a grocery store is just two blocks away. Will stay here again when we come back to Oahu. Towels & beach mats at the front desk to use.

We stayed here the last 2 days of January. I picked it mainly because we were renting a car for 2 days at the end of our 3 week vaction...and parking was free. Reviews were good and we had stayed in all ocean front rooms till now...so, why not save a few bucks now that we've seen enough ocean from our balconies. It was not very modern looking as we approached for the first time.....but, what a nice surprise for us as we openned our room door. Large and clean deluxe room with a very nice view over the canal/mountains. Room also had a kitchenette ....although we were done with any cooking. I would find it hard to describe the warm feeling here. It was mentioned in a few posts...the feel of aloha from warm, friendly staff was everywhere. People were welcomed back...and some were hugged good-bye. I would return at some future time.

The Ilima Hotel is our "go to" default choice when we go over to Oahu for most any reason. It is back near the Ala Wai and well off the noisy beaten path of Kalakaua or even Kuhio but convenient to most everything. Stayed there again this week while attending The PADI Business Academy at the Outrigger on the Beach. Ilima was 1/3 the price, super large room, free parking, kitchenette, wired & wireless internet and a comfortable bed (not a Westin Heavenly bed, for sure but slept well) and a mere 10-15 minute walk to the meeting. Always friendly & attentive staff as well.

Great staff who all seem genuinely happy to be working here. Super clean. Other reviewers have mentioned that's the Ilima is an older hotel, which is true, but it's been updated where it needed to be updated. Great views of the canal and the mountains if you're above the 8th floor. Close to everything you'd want.

A group of friends on a budget shared a two bedroom suite. The beds were comfortable including the Murphy bed in the living room. There was a kitchenette, clean bathroom and even a lanai. The AC was old school but pumped cold air once it kicked up. The suite is spacious but the style is "retro". The hotel could use a facelift but it was clean, affordable and well-located. Walking distance to restaurants, the International outdoor market and Waikiki beach, The Ilima is a great bargain!

The front end staff are excellent and very helpful. The room was very clean and huge. We stayed in the deluxe suite with a full kitchen and were very impressed with the dishes and stuff they supplied. They even had a jug of ice water in the fridge waiting for us. The hotel is not on the beech but only a short 5-10 min walk. Very close to the international market. All in all a great experience.

First visit to Honolulu. Looked for a hotel in Waikiki with free parking and free internet. This was one of only two that came up. Very spacious room with two queen beds, on the ninth floor.Great kitchenette with full size fridge, four burner stove, microwave, and all the cooking utensils we needed. Very pleased. The rooms have hard-wired internet only. For wireless access you need to be in the lobby. No problem for us, we just plugged in the internet cable that was in the room into our netbook.Might have been a little bit of noise outside late at night... but that's what we get for keeping the patio door open.You get one free coffee packet the first day. After that you need to pay $1 for a coffee package from the Kauai Coffee Company (we later went to the Kauai Coffee Company in Kauai, and found they were selling the same for $1.50).As for cost... not bad. Can't complain. Paid for four nights, had the fifth free (they had a promo going on; might be an ongoing promo).Very clean and within 5 minutes walking distance to Waikiki beach.Parking was limited, but we had no trouble finding parking each night we were there in late January.

Woke up at 4 am and couldn't get back to sleep so here I am....This hotel was perfect for our purposes. We flew into Honolulu yesterday morning and are leaving on the Pride of America cruise this afternoon. We wanted a place in Waikiki to stay in Waikiki last night. It's a 10 minute walk to the beach and all the stores in Waikiki. A 5 minute walk to the Magic of Polynesia show which we saw last night (a must see!). The price is right, the staff are very helpful and friendly and the parking is free if you arrive early enough in the day to get a spot. The only downside is wifi is free but only available in the lobby, but they said they are planning to have it available in the rooms next month. No hesitation in recommending this hotel.

My family stayed here (suite803, 2bdrm superior suite) for 1 week in late January. It was everything that was expected. ~ price $220/nt (reserved online, using the 'hot deals' option)~ location was great! Virtually steps away from the international market and very close to good eats! Food pantry was 2 blocks away. Downside was that we heard sirens, garbage trucks, tire squeals every night. That's the price for being in the heart of Waikiki.~ free parking. We always found a parking spot but they are a tight squeeze so I wouldn't recommend renting anything larger than a mid-size car.~ spacious! 770 sq ft apartment with all the kitchen amenities! Air conditioning in bedrooms and living room~ our balcony looked out to Nohonani street but turning right there was a beautiful view of the canal and the mountains~ friendly staff was available 24hr/day. We had late check-in and early check-out. There was always a friendly person to help.~ coin laundry ($1.50 washer/ $1.25 dryer) there was a clothes basket for use in our room too! How thoughtful!~ small pool and gym looked nice but I didn't use them~ beds were comfortable but if you could bring your own sheets it would be recommended~ free plug for internet. I brought my own wifi router and had internet. If not, you can go to the lobby to use the wi-fiEverything was clean and comfortable. If they would just do some maintenance like de-scale the lime on the shower head or repaint the bubbling walls it would be perfect.

When my wife and I were planning our first-trip ever to Hawaii, we began looking for hotels and our first stop was Honolulu. We wanted to stay near Waikiki Beach but we didn't want to pay the exorbitant prices for the hotels on the Beach. A cousin recommended the Ilima Hotel and it was right-on. It was a perfect place for us. A block and a half from the Beach and very close to all the specialty shops and restaurants on the Beach. We had a car and the proximity of the hotel to Pearl Harbor, Diamondhead and the main route of H-!, made it very easy to get to. And, the parking at the hotel was free!!! The room was very big as it had a kitchen along with a table and chairs...There was also a very nice deck off our room so we were able to sit and have breakfast...The staff couldnt have been nicer especially assistant manager Jay. He was there to give us tips of where to eat and how to get to the places we wanted to see. And, he always had the right map for us...There was also a coin-op washer and dryer so we were able to do our laundry...They also had a small business center so, for a slight charge, I was able to print up some emails I received...If you are looking for a hotel in Honolulu that is convenient and reasonable with a wonderful, helpful staff, don't go any further than the Hotel Ilima.

I spent a couple of nights in room 1207 (a Studio Deluxe) in early January. For $140 a night, you won't find a better hotel room in Honolulu during that time of the year. Just make sure you book from their website and select "Hot Deals" from the drop-down menu when getting a rate. Their Superior Studios (one notch down from my room) go for $130 a night and if you find availability for 5 straight nights, you'll get the 5th night free - which works out to an unbelievable $104 a night!The hotel itself is very well located, the staff is kind and efficient, and rooms are clean, functional and quiet. The only noise I heard was due to the wind - my room was facing the Ala Wai Canal and the mountains, and although the view was amazing (rapidly moving clouds and frequent rainbows), it did get noisy at times with the trade winds constantly blowing.My lanai was really nice, with two comfortable chairs and a small coffe table. All rooms come with an HD 32-inch LCD television with lots of channels and excellent reception.The hotel has two elevators and unlike some other (larger) hotels in Honolulu, you won't have to wait forever for an elevator. There is no pool at the hotel but the beach is only a 10-minute walk away. Reception staff will provide you with complimentary beach towels and you will find free wired Internet (ethernet cable provided) in the rooms. I carry my own pocket wireless router and was able to easily set up a wireless connection in my room (otherwise they have free wireless in the lobby).No breakfast is provided but all studios come with a kitchenette, and I was able to buy everything I was looking for from the Food Pantry grocery store on Kuhio, a 5-minute walk from the hotel. The Food Pantry is well stocked, has competitive prices and houses an excellent prepared foods section (including fresh sushi and a small Japanese food counter) by the entrance. And don't forget the amazing udon place (Marukame Udon) which is right around the corner from the hotel on Kuhio Ave. What else can you ask for?

We spent a week at the Ilima - four days pre-cruise and three days post-cruise. We must have dealt with every member of the front desk staff, and found everyone to be pleasant and helpful. They had helpful suggestions on places to eat and how to travel, and followed up when we returned and asked about our experience.The hotel is not new, but seems well maintained, and the rooms are large. Watch the hotel's web site for specials, and ask for a canal-facing room. The kitchen facilities are a nice bonus.

If you're looking for luxury, this isn't the place for you. If you just need a place to bathe and lay your head after a day of sightseeing, this is the place for you. We were only in the area for a couple of days so it was fine. I couldn't see myself staying here for longer than that. No wifi in the room and the room just felt really old. It was clean though and the front desk staff was very helpful and friendly. Location was also central to many things.

We stayed Jan 9-18 in a two-bedroom suite and found the property to be everything weexpected (with the exception of in-room wi-fi- our mistake; only high speed free in-roominternet access advertised ). Neighborhood was noisy, but worth it for the convenience oflocation. Fitness room has 2 cardio machines only, but in new condition. Laundry rooma big help. Free parking on a first-come, first-served basis (excellent buses and centrallocation made car rental unnecessary for us). Our suite looked exactly like the photos on the website. Would definitely return.

This was our fifth time staying at the Ilima over the past decade. We will be back again, maybe next Christmas. This stay was for 10 nights, over both Christmas and New Year's Day. The prices at this time are of course at their highest, but still good value for Waikiki.The lobby is actually quite stylish--perhaps Art Deco--and quite inviting. The front desk staff are always pleasant and helpful, and efficiently get guests registered. I sat in the lobby to play on my ipad in the evening and was amazed to see how many people are frequent visitors. One man had been coming with his partner for decades!The pool is small and too shady, but it is hardly used at all. My son used the gym and found it helpful, but he said it didn't have weights.Rooms are large and have functional kitchens with microwaves and small stoves. Decent size fridge. Parking is tight but free. Most days there was room, but you need to pay for parking across the street if the lot is full.The hotel gives towels and mats for the beach.Everything is clean.But the best thing about the Ilima is the people, many who have worked there for years. Ema is best! (Management seems to treat staff well--I heard the managers talking about a staff member who messed up a reservation, but they just chuckled and found a way to resolve the issue. I'm not sure that the staff member even learned he had erred!) We have made friends with some people, and know other guests have visited staff at their homes.It is not the fanciest place in Waikiki, but as I said, we will be back...

We stayed from January 17, 2013 until January 20, 2013.The front desk was extremely helpful and pleasant. The lobby and common areas were clean and very functional.The bedroom was very large and comfortable. We had 2 double beds a nice bathroom and a kitchen area. The hotel is very central and if you want a vacation hotel that is not part of the large impersonal chains then this is a place for you and your family. We met guests who have been coming annually for in excess of 20 yearsIt is good value and we would stay there again. WE recommend it.

We stayed at the Ilima Hotel in the beginning of October. We took a cruise around the islands on Norwegian Cruise Lines We actually stayed here four nights before our cruise and returned for two nights after our cruise. The Ilima hotel is not a luxury hotel. I think some people expect a little too much considering the reasonable price paid ($139/night) for a hotel two blocks from Waikiki beach. It was reasonably clean and the staff cleaned the room every day, providing fresh linens. The front desk staff was always helpful and pleasant. The full kitchen was great. We ate most of our meals in the room, buying food at the local Safeway or at a seafood fish market. It’s a great way to save time and money. We did have a car, which is the only way to really get around Oahu. There is free parking at the hotel which consists of the lower three floors of the hotel, as a parking garage. We didn’t have any problems finding a parking spot, but, I could see how that could be challenging at night.One room was facing Waikiki beach, however, you really can’t see the water from the balcony, even on the upper floor of the hotel. The view is pretty much, the tops of buildings. The second room overlooked the Ala Wai canal and golf course. You could see the beautiful hills from the balcony. The view is much better on the east side, but the traffic noise seems to be louder. We walked to the beach daily, its about two blocks. Sunset from the beach is not to be missed. There are small shops every where in the beach area that range from extremely expensive to very reasonable. When visiting tourist sites in downtown Honolulu we took the bus as parking is non existent or very expensive. We used the car to visit the rest of the island. The room pictures included in many reviews is very accurate as to what the rooms are actually like. All in all I have no complaints about our stay at the Ilima hotel and I would definitely stay there again when I revisit.

I tried this hotel because someone I know liked it a lot and highly recommended it. I have to say I am disappointed and was expecting more. Ilima Hotel is not rundown but all it really need is cosmetic updating of the room and bathroom. The rooms are spacious with a kitchen, table and chairs so it is good for a couple or small family of three. The hotel does have free parking for guests but don't rent a large vehicle because the parking space is tight and it is not easy to maneuver around. In addition, parking is limited and don't be surprised if you end up having to park on the street. There is an outdoor pool but it is really for sitting and relaxing so don't expect to do laps. From the hotel, you can pretty much walk to a lot of the attractions in the area. One thing I want readers to be aware, the adjoining hotels on the block seem a bit shady and seedy so do be careful walking alone at night.

The hotel is located in well known Waikiki area. We reserved a two bedroom suite. The drawback was one bathroom which is certainly not acceptable for the family of four. However staff was friendly particularly the housekeeping lady. Our toilet got clogged on which was promptly taken care of on a single phone call. We may try it next time but not surely.

Stayed there during Christmas 2011 ,a bit outdated but everything was functional ,close to most attractions and busses. Short walk to beach and shopping ,no food available in hotel some vending machines but grocery store a few blocks away. Stove and frig. in room were adequate great for cheaper meals , staff very friendly and tours arranged in lobby by very knowledgable senior citizen . Pool not huge but good enough to cool off in, didn't use fitness center. Try to get room facing inland or on upper floors to eliminate street noise downtown side has some noisy bars nearby. Very enjoyable.

Overall good bargain for stay in Waikiki area. I mean stay. If you travel with children you need a reasonable swimmingpool, witch we saw from our balcony facing to canal and mountains, howeverthe sun never shinedon to our balcony. The wiev is better at this side.Rooms are nice and roomy,outdated furniture with fridge and stowe. Also plates and eating tools, basic cooking material is provided, just bring salt and pepper, they get you started. We made our breakfast everyday at room.Prices are higher in Waikiki area, but if you rent a car, you find nice supermarkets outside. You will find that eating out in any place in Waikiki is average mininimun 20 $ with a drink, small pizza 18$.Hotel has complementary parking, but the slots are a bit narrow so you dont want rent a big car.Friendly staff in this hotel, cleaning everyday, so I might think coming back just for few days as a couple,Mahalo.

My family and I stayed here for nearly 2 weeks in a standard studio. The rooms were big, clean and comfortable. It was very handy having a kitchen and the good sized fridge stored plenty of food and drinks. We had a view of the canal and the hill behind it in the distance, which at night sparkled with lights from the houses. Close to shops, the market place, restaurants and a short walk to the beach. The pool was refreshing in the heat. The staff were very nice and helpful. The price we paid was good value and we were very happy with our stay. We would stay here again.

We stayed in Ilima Hotel 21.10.-28.10.12 7 nights in the 5th floor facing the city to Nahua street. The room was quiet, clean and spacy. A highlight defintely is the courtesy garage where we always found a free lot. The small fitness center (no airco) is next to a Sauna which fortunately was not used by anybody – this could be a problem because it will get hot on the training equipment. The hotel is centrally situated in Waikiki with restaurants and shops in walking distances and larger supermarkets in short riding distance. .All in all a good deal for a comfortable stay in WaikikiThe management did a good job during a Tsunami warning on our last evening in keeping people informed.

I stayed at the Ilima 35 years ago. Only thing that I notice that has been updated since then is the lobby. It's a budget hotel in the hub of it all. For those commenting on the noise. It's Waikiki... It's a city with a famous beach. It's full of tourists shopping, creating garbage and noise. The noise pollution is just a fact of life, as with any other urban centre. The staff were all helpful and courteous. But a extra special shout out to Dayna and Robin!! (Dayna will you marry me?) ;) You can save money on food due to the fact the Ilima provides a full kitchen. Otherwise you're looking at somewhere near $10 per person, per meal when eating out. That adds up quickly if you're with a family. That being said, you will be a little taken aback by the grocery prices at nearby Foodland and ABC. I suggest bringing from home some "to go" packets of salt, pepper, mayo, catsup. Whatever various seasonings and condiments you enjoy, as there were none in the room. A tiny bottle of mayo set me back over $4. (But it was Thanksgiving weekend, so very few deals on anything.) There's a safe in the room, for a $2.50 per day charge. I brought my own beach towel. They do offer free towels and roll-out bamboo mats. But I found the towels supplied to be quite small. It made for a good beach pillow though. :) At tip to save over 40% on your room rate. Book directly through the hotels website. Pick your dates. Click the drop-down where it says "Rack," and click on "Hot Deals." My rate went from $178 to $100 p/night. You're not going to beat that in Waikiki. I paid more to stay at the Ohana East last year, and I would definitely recommend the Ilima over the OE for room size, cooking facilities and bed comfort alone. (OE had the worst bed I've ever slept in.) You're not going to find glitz n glamour. But it's clean. It's roomy. It's reasonable. It's just a couple blocks from the beach, and right near the thick of things. As long as you're not expecting some posh accommodation... I totally recommend it!

we arrived nov 28 for a 23 night stay as soon we got in to the room we smelled mold the room was dirty i removed the pitifull air cond.cover i never seen so much mold in to a unit before, made us sick i called the front desk to report the problem and to be moved to onother room she er response was that she had specific instructions from the manager not to move us from the roomthe following day the air cond. was replaced and the maint. man left a 3inc gap all roud the unit so i went out got maskin tape and fix it my self this hothel only cater to our friend from japan not us from the main land we are from florida bottom line this place is dirty smelly and old

Stayed for 9 nights in November 2012. Did not get one good nights sleep as road noise was dreadful. Not only the cars and noisy mopeds, but people yahooing to all hours, garbage trucks at five in morning etc etc.Ear plugs did not even help! We were on the 8th floor at front and asked to be moved after first night but all the 2 bedrooms faced the road. Room was ok . Old but relatively clean. Beds very hard. Close to shops and restaurants. Was bit disappointed after reading all the great reviews about friendly staff as quite often felt like I was intruding on their conversations when approaching the desk for assistance. Overall was disappointed after picking this hotel based on the good reviews on this site.

We stayed at this hotel twice this November (2012). Great location (two blocks from the beach and near a lot of restaurants and the International Market), really good sized rooms and the front desk/service staff are outstanding. Not fancy but clean and well appointed. Why would you want to pay more??

My wife and I recently stayed here for 6 nights and have to let you know that it is a bargain and nice hotel with a fantastic location. We had a high floor (14th) that overlooked the Ala Wei Canal. That also gives you a view of the mountains from your lanai.You are only blocks from the International Market and also from the beach. The hotel has mats and towels for you to borrow and use at the beach.If you like to run, as I do, this is a good place to run as you don't have to cross streets running from one end to the bridge and back again. It also has nice scenery and many other runners too.If you rent a car, the hotel is one of the few to offer free but limited parking. During high season it might be hard to find a spot if you come back to late in the day but there are many places to go to locally in the evening here too.You should check out the special that are offered by the hotel. Just click on the specials at the top of their web page. We spent only $120 a night plus tax for this place and we are going to come back and stay here again. Try to get a room higher up so as to be away from any street noise and to get a better view of the area.This hotel also has a laundry room so you can bring less cloths with you.

The great location, full kitchens and general comfort have brought us back here 5 times. Each room has a full kitchen, its own large water heater, and plenty of storage. It is close to a grocery and bus lines, covered parking is free, and it is along the quiet canal instead of the crowded beach. It is in Hawaii's busiest tourist area, yet the hotel employees are all friendly and act like the Ilima is a great place to work (one told me some staff have been here over 20 years). The building is looking dated, but it is comfortable and reasonably well-maintained: everything works and there are no smells of mildew, mold, or deodorizers. The photos on Ilima's website show the rooms accurately. We learned to get a 1-bedroom suite because the premium gets us extra space, a sleeper-sofa (so we can sit someplace other than a bed), and windows on 3 sides for excellent ventilation (not to mention some nice views). The king bed was comfortable, and the A/C cooled the bedroom well for sleeping.For in-room Internet, bring your laptop for the free hard-wired CAT5 connection; only the lobby has wifi. In-room Internet was adequate to check email, news, weather, and maps. Speeds were consistently slow during our week's stay (.8-.9 Mbps), connections dropped periodically, and in-room access was available to only one hard-wired device at a time. I enabled the virtual router on my Windows 7 laptop, and it sent usable wifi to my tablet.

Why would you spend huge $$$ on Waikiki accommodation when you can stay in this little gem? We've just returned from 7 nights at the Ilima Hotel and would go back any time. Huge rooms with wonderful views (we looked out over the mountains), big comfy beds, a little kitchenette, free parking, free internet, lovely staff, and right in the centre of everything!!!!! So glad we chose to stay here!!!!!

We stayed at the Ilima Hotel which I booked on Booking.com. It is located a couple of blocks off Waikiki and is near the Ala Wai Canal. Our room was on the 15th floor (it has 16 floors) and was a 'Deluxe King Studio' for $122 plus tax. It had a king and queen bed and a small kitchen area. Very nice space with nice views of the city and a little bit of ocean. The lobby staff was nice. My only two negatives are 1) no wifi in room and 2) no hotel guide. There is wired internet in the room and wifi in the lobby. Both are free. The guide to the hotel is minor, but it could show where the pool, exercise room, and laundry are. The location is fine, being half a block from Kuhio Street where the bus stops are.

I needed to book a room only for 2 nights in Waikiki so I chose Ilima hotel because of the good reviews in several sites. The hotel staff was very helpful and welcoming but I was a little bit dissappointed from the old furniture, decoration and bad smell in our room. Another frastrating thing was that there wan't wifi in rooms. The good thing with the hotel is that is in Waikiki- few minutes distance from the center of the town, the low price (if you are in budget is perfect to stay there) and the nice view of the canal and the mountains. I shouldn't forget to mention that the room was huge and clean and also we had free parking place which is rare in Honolulu.

We needed a place with a kitchen, and a friend suggested this place. We live on one of the neighbor islands and were here for drs. appointments. It is an older, comfortable place with helpful, friendly staff. We weren't able to get a room on the quieter Ala Wai Canal side but things were just fine.The location is convenient , and the hotels provides excellent directions. Parking was never a problem for us and is FREE, which is unusual here.We appreciated having ice already made for us in the freezer as well as cold water in a pitcher. Those of us who live in Hawaii know you don't get cold water from the tap.We we disappointed that we did not have wi fi in the room, only the lobby, however, you can plug into the Internet in your room if you have a laptop.We found the beds comfortable and loved the fact that you could have soft sheets and a soft blanket instead of the trendy heavy fluffy duvet cover things.

I was there from October, 13 to 17th, 2012. I choose this hotel becuase the location, price and the reviews I read in Trip Advisor.I felt confortable to recommend this hotel. Like I sad worth the price I payed. The staff is very nice, the room is good and clean.

We stayed here from 19th August to 2nd September - what can we say, we loved every minute of our stay here the Satff (particularly Shaun and Dayna) could'nt do enough to help us and always had a smile and an ear to listen to us gushing about Hawai'i (even though they must have heard our touristy stories a million times before) Rooms were clean and comfy but a little dated. Rooms were huge and we had a view of the Canal and golf course. This was a "once if a lifetime" trip to celebrate my 50th Birthday and we travelled with our Son (23) and Daughter (15) and never once were we concerned about their well being around the Hotel - if you, like us, are travelling 8,500 miles then do hire a car and drive around the Island since Oahu is truly spectacular - I hope one day to return

The staff were exceptional!! Thank you Courtni, for booking us an amazing room on the 9th floor with balcony overlooking the canal, mountains and golf course. Thank you also that I was able to relax with a cigarette on the balcony - not easily done in Hawaii with the tough anti-smoking laws. The hotel was clean and roomy, a block away from the shops and buses and 2 blocks from the real hustle and bustle of Waikiki which made it the perfect getaway. Every staff member was polite and eager to please as far as possible. Emi, thank you for the lei that you had made. Your generosity surely made me feel like real family receiving a lei in the traditional manner. This low price, high value hotel must be high on your list for consideration. Having a small kitchen meant we saved heaps on food, especially breakfasts. A quick stroll up to the next block to one of the many ABC shops where you can pick up salads, sandwiches, liquor, lollies and anything else you may want left us with plenty of change. All in all, we were delighted.

We stayed at the Ilima Hotel in Honolulu (Waikiki) mid September this year (2012) for 6 nights pre-cruise and then 1 night and a day post-cruise..We were exceptionally pleased with the location, value for money, room size and hotel staff.Location - Waikiki, steps from Kuhio Ave - so - VERY close to stores, restaurants and public transit. It was about a 10 minute walk to the beach. Because Nohonani is a side street it is MUCH quieter than the main streets of Waikiki.Value for money - I researched possible hotels in Waikiki in detail because we had some very SPECIFIC requirements in a hotel:Kitchen (at least kitchenette)Good bedding for 3 adultsLargish roomNear public transitNear a grocery store or well-stocked convenience storeLaundery faciities on-siteRating well for cleanlinessWithin Walking distance of the beachThe Ilima had all these and more:Full kitchenKing-sized bed AND large Double BedLARGE room2 blocks from a bus stop3 blocks from a grocery storesmall but adequate laundromat on site  In addition the Ilima has a small pool and a sun deck.We LOVED the fact that we could mostly turn off the AC and open the windows.Hotel staff were always helpful and friendlyThe room was kept clean and supplied.It is not a fancy resort-style hotel but it was perfect for our needs since it had all that mattered to us. I would highly recommend it to budget minded travellers with similar needs.

This is a great choice in Honolulu if you don't want to spend a lot of money. As others have mentioned, it is certainly dated. And I can't remember the last time I saw a range top covered in aluminum foil! But it's in a good location within a 5-minute walk to Waikiki (though the bus to Pearl Harbor took an hour and 15 minutes). We arrived early in the morning and they were able to check us in right away. We had a huge room on the 16th floor with a beautiful view out over the canal and the mountains. Staff was very friendly and helpful (but do not take their recommendation that you eat at the Atlantis - horrible place). We didn't like the fact that you had to pay for internet access - both in the room and in the lobby, but the free newspapers were welcome. And we're not sure what the deal was with the TV. Every channel we accessed seemed to have nothing but infomercials on it. One thing we noticed was that we had a constant draft - complete with noise - from the vent over the oven, but it did provide some ventilation! And we loved the fact that there were 2 luggage stands - helpful when there are 2 travelers! We would stay here again.

Even thought this hotel is not near the beach but the walk to public Kuhio beach only 10 min which is next to resort's Waikiki beach.The room is big with everything you need for stay longer,which includes all the kitchen wares and coffee maker(you need to buy the coffee for $1 a pack).The hotel is near the Ala Wai canal and you have great view if you ask for the room facing the mountain.The staff are helpful and only problem is you can get free Wi-Fi at the lobby.

Great staff and location: 2 blocks from beach, 1 block from International Marketplace. Good size lanai facing the beach. Nothing fancy, but everything I needed. The kitchen came in handy and it's important to save dough for souvenirs. I highly recommend making breakfast and packing lunches for daily beach trips because Oahu is expensive. Tip: bring a small cooler, Tupperware, and water canisters! There's a Food Pantry 2 blocks away where you can stock up. What I really enjoyed was the free shell/kukui nut lei making class through the hotel. There is a laundry facility on each floor. Most importantly, the hotel is clean, charming pink color, inexpensive and centrally located. I left our housekeeper a nice tip for their great service. I will definitely stay there again next time in Oahu. Mahalo!

My cousin and I enjoyed a week at this hotel. The room was good-sized with a small but full kitchen and private lanai--really a serviced studio apartment with two double beds. It's a 5-min. walk to the beach and located just off Kuhio where all the Waikiki buses stop. There are lots of eateries in the neighborhood. The complex has laundry facilities and a pool (we didn't use the pool, and note it is small and shady--the beach is "much mo bettah"). You can borrow beach towels and mats at reception. Also, shuttle service to the airport is just $10 when booked through reception. Our room was a bit "tired": the bathroom sink had a crack (which had been repaired) and the wallpaper was starting to peel at the corners, but it was pretty clean, everything worked, and the room was comfortable. Get a room with a mountain view if you can; ours looked out over Waikiki and got the afternoon sun through the ranch sliders without much breeze--the other side of the building would be nicer. Given the reasonable rate, large room size, full kitchen, comfortable feel, and convenient location, we'd happily stay here again. Good value for money.

Arriving at the Ilima at 6:00 AM after more than 24 hours underway (8 hours wait time at Las Vegas Airport) dead tired, the check-in clerk greeted us in true gracious Hawaiian fashion and suggested that after we ate breakfast at a nearby 24 hour restaurant (Dennys), the regular daytime manager could probably let us check in at 8 AM. True to her word we got a large pleasant room with a view of the mountains and the Ala Wai Canal and golf course. The studio room with full kitchen was definitely very dated (circa 1960s), but the room was comfortable, very clean, and it soon became our happy home for the next 10 days in Honolulu. The location was very convenient; near restaurants, a super market and best of all one block to Kuhio St and buses going all over Honolulu. The kitchen was bare bones as far as kitchen amenities, e.g. there was a coffee maker but no filters or coffee, no salt or pepper shakers, no sugar. A quick 3 block walk to the supermarket got us yogurt, orange juice, milk, bananas, corn flakes and Kona coffee. We ate breakfast in the room on a daily basis, not so much to save money, but CALORIES. The stove looked like the one we had 49 years earlier in our first apartment, but we used the oven only to heat up leftover rolls and some wonderful blueberry scones. The fridge was fine, as was the microwave where we heated up our many delicious leftovers from suppers out. What was especially nice about our room was that it was on the quieter side of the hotel so the incessant noise of life in Waikiki wasn't as pronounced as at some of the fancier hotels nearer the beach where vehicular noise goes on 24 hours non-stop. We would recommend the hotel to people not expecting luxury or beachfront exotica and who are satisfied with a LARGE clean very adequate though dated hotel room. The hotel is probably not your Honeymoon dreamy romantic love nest. Housekeeping was generally great and twice when a couple towels were missing, they were supplied within minutes. We would stay there again. By the way I chose this hotel for us based on Tripadvisor guest ratings and they described the Ilima perfectly.

This is not a 5 star neither it charges you like 5 star. It's an average hotel with great helpful staff. If you are looking for a budget hotel in waikiki.. not many can compete with Ilima.We took 2 studio rooms here. They made sure we both were together next to each other and free upgrade for 1 room. Then the service, it was spontaneous. We called room service 3-4 times during our stay. Every time, we got our stuff within 5 minutes.They always tried to accommodate us, even with late checkouts. Helping us out with near by places.Pros:1)Cheap2)Spacious rooms.3)Full kitchen - with oven, microwave, full refrigerator and lots of utensils.4)Free Parking - In waikiki parking is $20-$30 per day. That's a big saving.5) Location - Waikiki is most hep place in Oahu. If you want a cheap stay in a happenning place. This is the place.6) Extremely helpful staff.Cons : can't think of any.Had a wonderful stay.Thanks to courtni/Karen(they booked our stay). Thanks to Emi, Diana they helped as us a lot during our stay.

The Ilima hotel is the most wonderful place to stay in Honolulu. Good, budget prices for the largest rooms I've ever seen. SOOO clean and neat. Such a safe feeling in hallways, garage, laundry, etc. The staff, Courtni, Karen, Juliet, Dayna, Emi, Shawn, Robert, Mr. B, Sui-Ana, Eme, just to name a few, are all dedicated, and professional. The Aloha at the Ilima is strong. We added an extra week on to the 4 wks already spent there. Only peeve--not having enough parking spaces so guests feel they can come and go as they please without losing the ability to park in the hotel garage. Having to drive around in circles and then walk 2 or 3 blocks can put a damper on the evening. Paying guests should have ASSIGNED stalls for their use only. Other than that I have only the very best to say about the building, and especially the great staff at the Ilima! Mahalo nui loa to all. We'll Be Back!!

We stayed @ the Ilima for 10 days with my four kids (2x19, 17,14 & 12) and one of my daughters friends. My first impression was omg..what did I get myself into but after the 1st day or so, there was no regrets. We had 2 deluxe rooms on the 15th floor facing the canal. You have to becareful though because the doors are quite heavy and if the sliding windows open you can really hurt yourself! So becareful! There is no Wifi in the rooms so you have to go down to the lobby..you get use to it after awhile but your really not there to play with your iPad. There is Internet connections in the rooms though. What was also nice is free parking! Kind of tight especially with mini van but if your a good driver like my hubby you should be ok..to be warned try to park early. If you get there after 9:00pm you maybe out of luck. You were close to the International market, Main strip and a great udon noodle place just around the corner. The staff was awesome! Especially the people at the front desk...they where so helpful and friendly and we had great conversations! The pool was quite small but that being said, my 17&14 loved it. You can't do laps but it was nice for a quick dip. We also went to a free lei making class which they provided on Wednesday am. They talked about where the nuts come from and you make necklaces. It was alot of fun and you get to take them home. How awesome is that. Please note, this is not a fancy hotel...if you want something fancy this is not the hotel for you. If you want a clean hotel with a full kitchen, free parking and close to the strip this is it but don't expect anything else. We had no regrets staying at the Ilima and we would definetly go back! Aloha!

Just finished a two week stay at this hotel and can really recommend it. This is a slightly older property with an excellent location right in the heard of Waikiki. Staff are very friendly and go out of their way to help. We stayed in a one bedroom apartment a could not fault the property for value, cleanliness and friendliness. Hope to return again next year and will definitely book to stay here again.

My husband and I had a 24-hr stopover in Honolulu on our way home to Sydney, Australia from Seattle, Washington. On our way to Seattle, we had stopped over in Honolulu for 5 days and stayed at the Aqua Aloha - while the hotel is fine, our room was quite tight. In an effort not to spend too much money, I booked at the Ilima especially because they offer free parking - a rarity in Waikiki when most hotels charge $15-$30 a night. I booked in a bit of a rush and was pleasantly surprised to find, upon checking in, that they had given us a room with two double-beds and a kitchenette! Big enough for 4 people!The room was clean, a little bit dated, but I personally think it adds to the charm of the place. I can't review the kitchenette as we didn't use it but everything seemed to be working fine. The location is also great - out of the way of too much traffic but near enough so you can walk to where the action is. Will definitely be booking here when planning a trip with family and friends!

Older hotel but still kept in good shape. We stayed in a 2 bedroom suite which was plenty of space for my family of 6. The suites only have 1 bathroom so that was a bit of a challenge. The suites also have a full kitchen which is good if you don't want to eat out for every meal. The location was good, just a 10 minute (at most) walk to the beach and only 1 block from the International Market Place. It seemed like there were 2000 ABC stores close enough to pick up any groceries or other items you might need. As for transportation, if you have a car the parking is free in the attached garage. If you don't have a car, the closest bus stop is 1 block away. Taxi ride to airport costs $35-40 each way and Walmart was $12-15 each way. The Hotel provides beach towels and also has some beach mats available. Hotel staff was excellent.

I would come back and stay at this hotel again. All of the staff was absolutley wonderful. The rooms are very clean and it's in a great location in the heart of Waikiki. We took a very short walk everyday to the shops and beach.

This was our first time staying at the Ilima and we were not disappointed. Yes, it may need to be updated, but it was everything as advertised. We had a nice view of the ocean, and the location was perfect. The staff was very helpful and friendly, our room was clean. We did use the kitchenette to cook and we appreciated the full size refridgerator. Best of all....the free parking was a great bonus. We will stay here again and my relatives will give the Ilima a try, as well!

This was my second stay at The Ilima and, once again, I was very pleased! The staff is wonderful, rooms are large, and there's a kitchenette! Close walking distance Waikiki Beach, shopping and restaurants. I plan on staying there again next summer. Great place and great price! Hats off to Courtni and all the attentive staff at the Ilima!

The Ilima was an emergency choice after I had to punch out of a bad choice hotel in downtown Hono. I was lucky to book 7 days the day of check in, so I wasn't expecting much. I was pleasantly surprised. Though 70ish and kind of dated, the Ilima is a great value hotel with a beautiful view of the Ala Wai Canal, full kitchenette and free parking (albeit quite tight for my GMC Acadia rental). You do have to park by 8:00 PM, or else you'll need to head to a pay lot (did that once) or park for free about a quarter-mile away (did that once). Staff is friendly and efficient. Location is great. Just walking distance to Waikiki and many great nearby restaurants like Side St. Inn and Ono's. The Ala Wai golf course is also close by. It's a great choice for $180/night.

I am giving this 4 stars based on a budget hotel. It has free parking. However it needs to be upgraded. Do not expect anything fancy. If you are looking for a hotel on a budget and don't care if the decor is old, then consider this hotel. Staff is friendly. Location is convenient. And again parking is free.

We made our third visit to the Ilima in June 2012 for the Pan Pacific Festival and can't wait to get back to Hawaii. The reception staff really made us feel welcome and remembered us as though we had only been there a few weeks before. (Our last visit was September 2011 for Aloha Festivals). They upgraded our room to a deluxe room (king size bed) with the mauka view we had requested. (The best view from your lanai in the morning or evenings). We were very happy with our accommodations which allowed us the option to have breakfast and dinners in. This hotel is very well located in Waikiki with the supermarket (Food Pantry) just two blocks away and easy access to The Bus and trolley stops. A short walk to the beach and Kalakaua Avenue; around the corner from Seaside Avenue too where many tours pickup and drop you off; so really convenient. Cross the street and you are in Duke's Lane or International marketplace for souvenir shopping if you are ready to do a little bargaining.Appreciated the updating that they have been doing since our last visit, and hope that they will continue, as some of the rooms would benefit from updating.

I'm looking forward to my second stay at the Ilima in February 2013, after having spent 9 days there last February. I have been to Waikiki many times, and I usually stay at hotels on Kuhio. Being on a side street (Nohonani) was much quieter. There is an Enterprise Rent A Car right across the street which is a plus too. The fully equipped kitchen helped us to save money by eating breakfast and several dinners in. The staff is very friendly and helpful, and the hotel has a Hawaiian sing-along and necklace making to give you a little taste of Hawaiian culture. Free on site parking saves a lot of money, although the parking spots are very small. We asked for a room that faced the Ala Wai Canal and had room 701. If I had to say anything negative, it would be that I don't like the strong smelling, perfume-y spray they spray in the room. Also the pool is pretty small which is typical for Waikiki, unless you're in one of the larger chain hotels. Overall, a great place to stay!

Nothing fancy - a bit of an aging beauty (if it was ever beautiful), but you're right in the heart of Waikiki with air conditioned rooms and full kitchenettes. Our room on the 6th floor was HUGE. The kitchenette actually included a full stove and oven (not just a hotplate), plus new TV with cable and free hi-speed internet. The beds and bedding are a bit threadbare, and the decor a bit dated, but if you're not spending much time in your room, this is not a big deal. Free parking, too. I really appreciate finding places like this that don't nickle and dime you for parking, internet, TV, etc. The pool and exercise room were kind of a joke though - don't bother.
Walking distance to beach, pool small, no king beds, close to grocery store.

The Ilima hotel was a very inviting place right off the start...we arrived quite late due to our flight time and the nice gentleman (sean?) was very helpful getting us checked in and comfortable. We were placed in a superior studio 7th floor facing toward Kuhio...we were very pleased with this direction as we could sit on our patio and have sun most of the afternoon...I am very lazy on vacation and enjoy sitting on the lanai right outside my room! The kitchen is a very practical style and we did cook some meals to save some money for other events and such. The bathroom is very nice and includes a real bathtub!!! That is a plus for me as again I am very lazy and enjoy relaxing in the tub after a fun filled day in Waikiki...the sundecks on the 10th and PH levels are awesome as well...I especially loved the view way up high...nice loungers and a quick elevator down to the room for a snack or beverage!!! The pool is very cute...small but warm!! So an early morning splash is comfortable....small patio to lounge mid-afternoon and convenient washrooms just inside the building...parking was a nice bonus although we only needed to park a few minutes here and there but it was nice to be able to park on the property for quick up and downs...we will be returning again for 10 days in october and we are very pleased to have discovered this wonderful gem in the middle of busy of Waikiki!!!!

My first impression of this hotel was not positive!! So it's just as well I stayed more than one night as things improved dramatically after an initial cool 'welcome' to the Ilima.I'd made the mistake of walking about 30mins to the hotel with a heavy bag in the 2pm sun, and -- although I didn't realise till later -- I was suffering a touch of heat exhaustion and/or dehydration when I arrived. I felt like I might faint and I needed water, which I mentioned to the reception lady when I arrived. But the staff on reception didn't seem to give a toss. I had a guaranteed reservation and there was no rush to check me in, so you'd think people in the hospitality business in a tropical place like Hawaii would have invited a guest who was feeling overwhelmed by the heat to take a seat (there are sofas in the lobby) and drink some water until she felt better. Instead I was hassled to provide my credit card and ID instantly, and when I didn't respond fast enough (because I was searching desperately for my bottle of water, feeling quite flushed and woozy), I was hassled again for my credit card as if there was some desperate urgency -- which there clearly wasn't. Some training in basic humanity would be a good idea for the staff who were on duty that afternoon!!Fortunately the initial terrible customer service seems to have been an aberration, as all my later dealings with the staff in this hotel were fabulous. All the other staff on reception were overwhelmingly helpful (eg. helping me to log into the free wifi in the lobby; confirming my shuttle transfer to the airport) and one staff member deserves a medal for her assistance that went way beyond the call of duty. When I realised I'd left a bag of shopping at a store, Eme offered to drive me over to collect it in her own time, having just worked a full night shift, and then she dropped me back at the hotel. This sort of caring, personal customer service can't be surpassed, and more than made up for the cold 'welcome' to the hotel a couple of days earlier. The Ilima Hotel should clone Eme!!The rooms were OK: nothing special, but quite satisfactory. They were 1960s-1970s style "motel" standard with a useful kitchenette, small but pleasant balcony, smallish flat screen TV, good crisp linen on so-so beds, air con, plenty of space. Although tired-looking, everything was nice and clean. I had one of the more expensive rooms on a high level, so the outlook was good though I didn't feel the room was great value for money. There's wired internet but sadly no wifi in the rooms (free wifi is available in the lobby, as is an expensive pay-per-use computer). I was very unimpressed to find a hotel still charging per day to use the in-room safe!! Hotels should be encouraging guests to keep their valuables secure, not gouging them by charging for a basic travel essential like somewhere safe to leave a passport, ipad or camera when going to the beach.The hotel's location is excellent. It's right by the canal, with a lovely outlook over the golf course and volcano in one direction. Going the other way, it's a block to tacky Kuhio Avenue with its nightclubs and souvenir shops (sadly this meant there was also a bit of a party crowd in the hotel on the long holiday weekend, though staff told me that was unusual). It's two blocks to walk to classy Kalakaua Ave, with its nice shops, arcades, and the beach. Overall, I was happy with my stay at the Ilima Hotel and I'd stay here again. I wouldn't recommend it to people who are looking for mod cons or style, but for those wanting a good, basic place to stay with cooking facilities, an excellent location, and a family-run feel, it's highly recommended.

Nice one night stay, conveniently located. The room was huuuuge and clean but a bit old fashioned. I've seen kitchens with more utensils, so if you need to cook, you'll have to keep it real simple because there's not tons of them. Hotel staff was helpful and free parking is really appreciable. To be on the safe side, you may inquire at the front desk for the parking "forecast". If the hotel is fully booked don't park there too late. By the way, there's free wifi in the lobby but not in rooms.

My husband and I have just spent 10 days at the Ilima Hotel.I chose the Hotel as it is one of the few Hotels in Honolulu where one can book a room on a smoking floor and not feel like an outcast.Overall, we were very happy with our stay at the Hotel. The location is great - the Bus stop is just around the corner, so too are 2 Starbucks cafes, an ABC store, a Pharmacy and the Food Pantry. An iHop restaurant and The Cheesecake Factory are also within walking distance.Our room was very good although I will say that if our room is any example, then the Hotel would benefit from updating the rooms a little - in particular the stove/cooker and the drapes. I noticed that the drapes in our room had small holes in them. That said, I still give the Ilima Hotel a score of 5 out of 5 because our stay at the Hotel was hassle very and very enjoyable. We had a hire car and free parking at the Hotel carpark was great. Granted the car parks were a little tight, but my husband managed to park without a problem.All in all, a great Hotel and we will definitely stay at the Ilima Hotel again on our next vacation/holiday to Hawaii.

The location for the hotel is great and very affordable. Our 10th floor room sort of overlooked the main street of Kuhio above the evening noise and there was a sundeck on this floor. Short walk to most of the restaurants and the beach is about a block and half away. The room we had was enough for my family of four with two beds and the kitchen is nice to have to avoid having to eat out all of the time. Parking is free limited first come first serve and big enough for a economy size car. Getting anything the size of a mini van is pushing it. Got a spot all 6 days there. Front desk staff was incredibly helpful with directions to various places, such as market, types of restaurants in the area, bus routes, getting a cab and especially finding a urgent call facility within walking distant when my youngest one got sick. Would really recommend this place for a simple place to sleep and cook in occasionally. The pricing is perfect for what you get. FREE parking, free WIFI in lobby and wired internet for the room, kitchen, bathtub/shower, and central location.Rennsen

Stayed in 7th floor 2B 1B with kitchen in May 2012 for 3 nights. Only reasonably priced place for 2 parents with 2 adult kids at only $ 190 a night in Waikiki. Living area was big, but BRs small. Free parking and no problem getting a space, but best to have a smaller car than our big Grand Marquee. Elevator takes you from your room to garage level. Was a long 3 to 4 block walk to beach, but no complaints, because walk takes you thru Marketplace, food court, shopping, beautiful blvd with Macy's, and upscale stores and restaurants on way to beautiful beach area. The hotel is dated, with older AC units, older bath and kitchen, and dated but nice rattan furniture. Staff is prompt and helpful. It is not luxurious, but if you are looking for a safe, convenient place to sleep and cook some meals, and do not need a resort experience, this is a good deal.

I have to thank to the collaborators of this site for the great suggestion: the hotel is really excellent. Its members, its localization, its very large accommodations, besides its fully furnished kitchen, were wonderful. It is really a hidden gem! And it offers a very rare thing in Honolulu: a garage for free... I strongly recommend it !

I've stayed at the Ilima Hotel for 5 nights in May 2012 on a trip to Hawaii with my girlfriend. The hotel offers great value especially when you count in the free parking and free Internet. I don't know of any other hotel that offers free parking in Waikiki. The parking is on a first-come first-served basis, but we never had a problem getting a free space. The lot is a bit tight, but for a compact or mid-sized car no problem at all.The rooms are huge and feature a full kitchen with fridge. That's great especially if you don't want to eat out every day. Everthing was clean. The bed was a bit uncomfortable, because to hard for my taste. Internet access was wired in our room, so you need to bring your notebook as it is not possible to connect directly with a Wifi only device like iPhone/iPad. They do have WiFi in the lobby. The location is about two blocks away from the beach so it's just a short walk to get there. I liked it a lot because it's not to noisy but not to far away from everything. Grocery stores / restaurants are just around the corner.Overall i can highly reccomend the hotel. I would stay there again.

I have stayed in the Ilima Hotel with my wife and 3 years old child during our vacation trip in Hawaii and we liked a lot the place. The hotel external appearance might be a bit old-fashioned, but the rooms are quite big, with full kitchen equipment and everything working fine, what was exactly what we needed. Location is excellent, close to all good points from Waikiki, but without the exorbitant prices hotels in that area usually have. The staff was always helpful with our requests for information and promptly helped us by getting a crib for our daughter (needed to pay an extra USD10/day for that though). The hotel provides free parking, what is a nice perk in an area where hotels usually charge between USD10 and USD25 for that.

Pros:Great location one block from the beachSafeVery nice balconies and large roomsFree parking, unheard of in this area from the chains that charge ~20-30/nightLow cost (~100/night)Great staffCons: Reminds one of a 1970 Howard Johnson's Beds are relatively old and hard, but sleep ableNice kitchen, but very dated bathsAll said, this. Is a very good value for a safe place to stay.

The Ilima hotel is very well located. It is a pleasant and easy walk to Waikiki Beach from the hotel and it is also close to the Ala Wai Canal. Our room on the tenth floor had a beautiful view of the canal, the golf course, and the mountains behind. Staff members are welcoming and helpful. The rooms are comfortable, pleasant, and well maintained. They have excellent facilities and are very spacious for Waikiki. The full kitchen is a great bonus. This was our second stay at the Ilima and we would definitely choose it for our next visit.

Wife and I have spent many nights here since the early 90's. If you don't mind being steps away from the noisy beach and Kalakala Blvd, this is without a doubt the best hotel in Waikiki. It is only a one block walk to the International Market place. Older, but very well kept up. Rooms (studios) are about the largest and best equipted possible. Save lots of money eating in the fully stocked kitchen, In particular, request a studio up as high as possible, facing the canal and hills. Wake up in the morning to a great view and trade winds blowing into your room (wife's favorite thing). Rooms are very well kept up daily by housekeeping staff. Price of rooms hard to beat for this area.The staff of this hotel from the manager on down are the friendliest possible. Start off with a call to the receptionist (Cortni) to get a "Welcome Home" feeling which follows through as soon as you walk through the doors. The desk staff are the friendliest I have ever encountered. Willing to do anything reasonable to help you. Another huge plus,- free covered parking. The pool isn't huge, but it's big enough for a comfy dip. We cannot praise the "bang for your buck" and "Home" feeling you get when you stay here enough.

We stayed here for one night in May 2012 after flying over from the Big Island. I knew this was a budget hotel and I had read various reviews on Trip Advisor. Although the prices were decent and the location was within walking distances from everything I was expecting a lot more. The free parking is a nice plus but the spots are tiny and thankfully it was empty so we had no issues parking our minivan. The lobby to the hotel is nice but the immediate area is grubby and I wouldn't walk out there at night. We arrived at 2:30 pm with a baby and I was informed that my room was not ready but the crib was in there. The lady at the desk was polite but not overly concerned that I was ready to check in and out my baby down for a nap. I waited until after 3 pm (yes check in is at 3 pm) and I had to hound them to get my room ready. At approx. 3:15 pm, I was allowed into my room which limited further my short stay on Oahu. The room itself was disgusting to say the least. We had a studio style room with full kitchen. There was a coffee maker but no coffee? Also our view was over a scary looking apartment type building and we stared directly at them. The pale pink colour of the hotel was also grubby and the whole hotel needs an update. To be honest, I wouldn't of stayed there for another night as it was that bad. The crib which cost us over 10 bucks a night was also crappy and I felt bad for putting my baby in it but what can you do. The room also has a strange smell coming from it. The beds are tiny and the pillows are paper thin. Neither of us slept very well in this room. If you want area but are on a tight budget then this hotel may be for you but I would upgrade and go somewhere else.

Great locationgreat pricenice staffshame about the cleaning crewpool was in the shade most of day during mayreally embarrased about the clean up , didnt tell reception staff about it but fishing under the bed and there was stuff from previous guests and huge dust bunniesbathroom wasnt too well clean either

The hotel is within walking distance of the shopping district of Waikiki and its own free parking ramp. The staff was not much help when asked how to get to places but we figured out where we were going ourselves. Would stay here again for the same price.

We spent two nights here prior to a cruise. The rooms were huge and included a full kitchen. We reserved the cheapest room they had and I was shocked at the size. The staff was very nice, especially the night desk person-Robin-who remembered everyone's name. It was about 3 blocks from the beach and there were restaurants nearby. It even had a small balcony...no view, but a nice breeze. There was plenty of free parking, although the spaces were small. The only downside was that the bedspreads and drapes were a little tired looking, but that did not matter to us. If we are ever in Honolulu again we will definitely stay at the Ilima.

This Hotel is priced squarely at the budget conscious traveller, particularly families and it achieves this brilliantly. Before I stayed here in the Summer of 2011 I spent days researching different hotels in Honolulu and I have come to the conclusion It is without doubt the best value hotel in the tourist precinct. It is also one of the very very few hotels with free parking. Given I hired a car here for 10 days (the length of my stay) this was a huge saving and really convenient to be able to park my car in the same hotel without paying ridiculous parking fees Although it has dated decor and furniture, the room was spotless as was all of the Hotel. The staff were always friendly and helpful and I honestly have not a single complaint about the place. I highly recommend it for the budget conscious family, for those that don't have an endless wallet. Also the Hotel was close enough to everything yet far enough back from the beach and the clubs that it was quite and relaxed.

We stayed for 7 nights in mid-March 2012 in a superior studio room on the 9th floor. The room was spacious and the bathroom appeared to be recently refurbished. We requested a smoking room with a view of the mountains and received both. It was handy having the small kitchenette for a longer stay. We tried using the air conditioning once but found it too noisy, however, having the balcony door open was sufficient to cool the room during the day. The location was excellent as it was only a couple of minutes walk to the closest bus stop and there are many eateries nearby. I would happily stay here again.
The Ilima offered us: an ideal location in Waikiki, family-friendly suites, very reasonable prices, a virtually private pool, a smart and attentive staff, a great HQ for a family holiday.

My family chose this hotel Mar.4,2012-Mar.19,2012 (rained 11 out of 14 days)because we wanted an area where we would be close to everything....plus the bonus of a kitchenette with a full size fridge, smoking room and a balcony,also the staff was excellent. Some of our not so bonus ' the scenery on the bacony made you feel like you were in Toronto, buildings everywhere. Having the patio door opcerscen all night you could hear the partiers until 5am and sirens, then it was the garbage truc

I booked this hotel once for a week through Expedia and due to flight cancellations I wasn't able to make it for the first night. Expedia was willing to move my reservation up one day, but the hotel refused to budge on scheduling. Instead of letting me move my 7 day reservation by one day and keeping my business, they charged for the first night and I ended up booking at another hotel for the remainder of the week. I was hesitant to try this hotel again, but thought I would give it a try again.The hotel lobby was very old and dated. I was hoping the room would be better, but it was the same- old, outdated, and in desperate need of renovations. The beds were horribly hard and obviously old. It was also rather dirty. There is a lot of room in the hotel, but it's not really usable unless you plan on having a rollaway bed. In fact, it was a bit of a drawback because it meant the tv was about 12 feet from the foot of the bed. The view was really unattractive, even for a city view. It's about two blocks back from the main strip in Waikiki and that 2nd block really makes a difference in the feeling of the surrounding area. Also, the free wifi is only in the lobby. We took one look around and knew that we weren't going to be happy with this at all. We went to talk to the front desk. They lightly apologized, but wouldn't give us our money back and wouldn't put us in a better room.I have been to Waikiki three times, always on a budget, and have found several other hotels that were better for less money even after their parking fees. I will not stay at this hotel again.

We stayed at the Ilima for six nights after returning from the week-long NCL four-island cruise. On the whole, we loved our suite (1101). I was surprised at how quiet it was (especially since I'm a light sleeper) despite being above a busy street and right next to the elevator. We had only two significant complaints. The first was that, when the hot water was turned on—even low, it made a loud shuddering noise. My partner said this wasprobably due to an air lock in the pipes. We were in a hurry checking out so we didn't have a chance to alert the front desk to this problem.( Hopefully, it's been addressed.) The second concerned the metal tray under the air conditioning unit on the lanai. We sat out there on a few occasions, but this thing didn't look like it had been cleaned in a very long time. It was full of deposits (grunge) and moss. I'm only glad that my niece and nephew visited us in the evening because I would have been embarrassed if they had seen it.
This hotel has the friendliest staff! The studio rooms are large and has all the conveniences you need for a small family on a short vacation.

I liked this place because of its location and the (free) parking space. They offer free WiFi even in the room and 1-800 numbers are to allowed without charge (good for oversea tourists with a calling card). I stayed only one night (first day after arrival) and everything was just fine. The room was clean and extremely spacious. The only thing to improve is that the furniture and the carpet have seen better times.

We had a large room. Location very handy and near bus lines. Could pick up breakfast items to keep in our kitchenette at nearby Food Pantry (urban grocery store with great produce) or the somewhat more expensive but ubiquitous ABC store. Nice pool for cooling off. I enjoyed a free lei making class that was offered once a week. Only downside was the street was fairly noisey in the wee hours and we were unable to keep our windows open for that reason. We chose not to take our laptop since we were doing a lot of island hopping. There was a computer in the lobby for use with fee. This worked fine.

Arrived in reception and this hotel looked very nice. they were very friendly at reception and checking in was very quick.have to say however when i got to the room I was dissapointed. The decor was old the bed was a small double. The balcony had no real view. air coditioning unit was extremely loud.The room looked untidy and dated. The kitchen was very compact and we didn't really feel like cooking there. the kitchen utensils were basic.The swimming pool was very small and there was some gym machines but not a varied selection. The loaction of the hotel was ideal for waikki and other tourist destinations. There was a travel conciege at the frontdesk to help with any travel plans (open half a day). overall the hotel was ok however in comparison to other hotels stayed in whilst travelling in Hawaii was poor.

Aloha! From booking to check out, extremely satisfied. We didn't spend a lot of time in Waikiki but this location was the best deal we could find and it was a great home base. The staff are really friendly, the hotel is very clean, there is an in room safe for your cash, passports and etc (if you feel you need it) and FREE PARKING (hard to come by) even though parking is first come first served we always managed to have a spot... the in room kitchen is a nice to have too! If you are looking for extras and expensive amenities to waste your money on (i.e. spa, golf, room service, etc.) then this is not the place for you... if you are looking for a clean, friendly and safe place to sleep and explore from, then look no further! Overall, great experience, great deal... We will DEFINITELY be back. Mahalo!

Stayed 10 days at the Ilima. The hotel is a little older but the room was big and the kitchen serviceable. It was clean enough to be healthy and sure, there were signs of wear and tear, but I've seen just as much in an over priced Las Vegas strip hotel. We were on the 12th floor, facing the Kuhio avenue. It is indeed very noisy, garbage trucks at 6 am but with a pair of ear plugs I managed. The staff did try to find us a room on the canal side when we asked to move, but unfortunately the hotel was full. The problem is the slat (or louvre) windows. They are single paned and clearly don't keep the sound out. It is also a good walk to the beach about 15 Hawaiian minutes. The staff are very friendly and helpful. Other than the noise complaints, the hotel is a good place to stay.

We stayed at the Ilima Hotel for 10 days. The room was unusually spacious with a large balcony and a kitchen, there is a proper bathtub in the bathroom. The beds were fantastic. The staff was very pleasant and extremely obliging to our wishes. There are even smokers' rooms in this hotel, unsual for the US and very convenient for us, as we didn't have to run outside for each cigarette. All in all, it was one of the most wonderful holidays of our life, we loved our stay in the Ilima Hotel and would always return to it again!
